Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: For years, Woods’ relationship with his longtime landlord has been deteriorating. About nine months ago, the two men agreed he could withhold rent until repairs were made, he said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: He left the courthouse without much hope.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Then, recently, his landlord caught him by surprise and filed for eviction. He couldn’t prove his missed rent payments were part of a verbal agreement, so the judge granted the property owner’s request and told Woods his family had 10 days to move.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: He left the courthouse without much hope.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The cash didn’t make it to MALS until February 2024, due to problems with how the County Commission resolution was originally drafted, Henderson said.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: But Henderson has been happy with the results since then.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Though the program has only helped a couple of tenants so far — not 300 — Henderson believes it’s already proving its value.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the court’s judges, Deborah Henderson; Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon; and Cindy Ettingoff, then-CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services, last summer secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Henderson believes the program will require a much longer pilot period before it’s able to produce the proof necessary to create a housing court. But, despite the rough start, she remains 'very hopeful' for its future.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the court’s judges, Deborah Henderson; Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon; and Cindy Ettingoff, then-CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services, last summer secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There are no income limits or income requirements,” Henderson told a WLOK-AM audience earlier this summer. “If you’re a tenant who is having trouble with your landlord, you need to give us a call. … If you’re a landlord and you have a troublesome tenant … give us a call.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the court’s judges, Deborah Henderson; Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon; and Cindy Ettingoff, then-CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services, last summer secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Nicole Grida, the new MALS CEO, said her team has started creating marketing materials for the program, building partnerships with local nonprofits and screening folks who call in for other services to see if they will fit the program’s criteria, which has resulted in many promising leads.
For the program to succeed, Grida said raising greater awareness will be key, as most Memphians it could help don’t yet know it exists.
Meanwhile, Grida said MALS is looking for other funders interested in backing the effort.
Woods’ case, for instance, sounded like a perfect fit for mediation, Henderson said, if only they’d found him before the eviction was filed.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the court’s judges, Deborah Henderson; Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon; and Cindy Ettingoff, then-CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services, last summer secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We could have drafted a document that ensured the landlord (followed the verbal agreement),” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the court’s judges, Deborah Henderson; Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon; and Cindy Ettingoff, then-CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services, last summer secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The initial goal was for MALS to use the money to hire a few employees — including a former code inspector since property conditions almost always drive the disputes. The nonprofit would then find tenants and landlords who seemed headed toward eviction and prevent at least 300 evictions — all in a year.

But receiving the money from the county turned into an adventure. The cash didn’t make it to MALS until February 2024, due to problems with how the County Commission resolution was originally drafted, Henderson said.

By then, Ettingoff was no longer with MALS, and the interim executive director, Loyce Lambert Ryan, was dealing with the fallout of a major cyber attack. Ultimately, MALS wasn’t able to launch the program in earnest until June.
Recently, MALS worked with a woman who was living in a house that 'should not be lived in by anyone' and was starting to fall behind on rent, Henderson said.

To drum up more business, Henderson and MALS attorney Cedric Harris, who is leading the program, have been spending a few nights and weekends this summer speaking to churches, on radio shows and at other events.
Interested in applying for Memphis Area Legal Services’ new landlord-tenant mediation program? Call 901-432-4663.
Its leaders are scheduled to present to the County Commission at the end of 2024, in hopes they can receive additional county funding after this first $240,000 runs out in February 2025.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes
